pages.text: $(l:materials/Indium)Indium$(/l) $(l:materials/Gallium)gallium$(/l) phosphide (InGaP), also called $(l:materials/Gallium)gallium$(/l) $(l:materials/Indium)indium$(/l) phosphide (GaInP), is a semiconductor composed of $(l:materials/Indium)indium$(/l), $(l:materials/Gallium)gallium$(/l) and phosphorus. It is used in high-power and high-frequency electronics because of its superior electron velocity with respect to the more common semiconductors $(l:materials/Silicon)silicon$(/l) and $(l:materials/Gallium)gallium$(/l) arsenide.$(p)It is used mainly in HEMT and HBT structures, but also for the fabrication of high

efficiency solar cells used for space applications and, in combination with $(l:materials/Aluminium)aluminium$(/l) (AlGaInP alloy) to make high brightness LEDs with orange-red, orange, yellow, and green colors. Some semiconductor devices such as EFluor Nanocrystal use InGaP as their core particle.$(p)Indium $(l:materials/Gallium)gallium$(/l) phosphide is a solid solution of $(l:materials/Indium)indium$(/l) phosphide and $(l:materials/Gallium)gallium$(/l) phosphide.
